title: cruel owner abandons elderly neglected
story: :root Cruel owner abandons elderly and neglected cat moments from death in plastic boxThe RSCPA is investigating after the cat was left cruelly abandoned in a Derby park covered in urine, barely breathing and had lost most of its teethThe cat before vets tragically had to put it down Image: RSPCAByMatthew LodgeShiler Mahmoudi:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsThe owner of a cat abandoned a cat in a plastic box as it was dying with RSPCA investigating the cruel act of animal abuse. The black cat was left to die in a plastic box in a park in Derby on Sunday September .According to Derbyshire Live, he was found soaked in his own urine and barely able to breath.The feline was skinny, had diarrhoea, infested with fleas and all its teeth had fallen out or were rotten. A passer-by alerted the RSPCA who took the elderly cat to a nearby vets straight away, but sadly they were unable to do anything and he had to be put down. Now the RSPCA is appealing to try and find the person who dumped the cat when it was at its most vulnerable. Pamela Bird, the animal rescuer who was sent to the scene, said: This poor elderly cat was in a neglected state, it’s heartbreaking that he was dumped at the side of the road when he deserved to have been surrounded by love and affection at the end of his le. I am keen to find out more about what happened and am hoping someone may have seen something suspicious or who may recognise the cat and can identy his owner. The cat carrier was broken at the front opening and he was lying on a copy of the Derbydated July , . I want to remind people that there are many charities that are willing to help people who have fallen on hard times and can’t look after their animals anymore and vets often offer payment plans to spread the costs of treatment. I would always urge people to call for help rather than abandoning an animal in this way. An owner has a responsibility to keep their animals safe from harm and pets deserve better.” Anyone with information should contact the RSPCA appeals line on    Comment MORE ON RSPCACatsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dad totally broken after happiest
story: :root Dad totally broken after his happiest girl killed in Killamarsh sleepover tragedyTerri Harris, , her -year-old daughter Lacey Bennett and -year-old son John Paul Bennett all died in the Killamarsh sleepover tragedy, as well as Lacey’s friend Connie, also Connie Gent was one of four to die in the tragedyByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  Sep The dad of a girl killed in the Killamarsh sleepover tragedy has been left totally broken by her death and the entire family has been destroyed, her uncle has said. Charlie Gentaposs little girl Connie Gent was one of four people found dead at a house on Chandos Crescent on Sunday morning. Thirty-five-year-old Terri Harris, her -year-old daughter Lacey Bennett and -year-old son John Paul Bennett all died, as well as Lacey’s friend Connie, also . Their bodies were found by officers who were responding to a call which came in at .am on Sunday. Damien Bendall, , has since been charged with the murders. He will appear at Southern Derbyshire Magistrates’ Court later today. Chris Gent described his niece Connie as the “happiest girl in the world” after the horrying tragedy.Chris, who is the older brother of Connie’s dad Charlie Gent, told The Sun: “Our entire family is destroyed.No parent or anyone should ever have to go through such a horric ordeal. “Charlie is totally broken. He is devastated. He can’t believe he will never see his daughter again.” Police were seen scouring bins and a nearby park on Monday as they tried to piece together the killing. Terri, John and Lacey are said to have not lived in Killamarsh for long, having moved from Sheffield. Neighbours said they had only lived there for a few months. More tributes were left at the scene on Tuesday as mourners continued to pay their respects.  Detective Chief Inspector Sally Blaiklock who is leading the investigation said previously: “Our thoughts remain with the families of Terri, John Paul, Lacey and Connie – as well as the communities that have been affected by this most tragic of incidents. “A large scene remains in place on Chandos Crescent and local residents will see an increased police presence in the area over the coming days, including patrols by officers in the local area. “I would urge anyone who is concerned about the incident to speak to officers in the area or use the online reporting tool to pass information in confidence. “Myself and the team of the detectives are particularly keen to hear from anyone who was in Chandos Crescent between pm on Saturday  September and am on Sunday  September, as well as anyone who may have video footage of the street. “That can include dashcam, mobile phone footage, CCTV or video doorbells.”Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Derbyshire PoliceMurder" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news emmys-snubbed-harry-meghans-oprah-"Meghan Markle: Experts on Oprah interview Emmy nominationByJenner Newton:,  Sep | commentsPrince Harry and Meghan Markleaposs bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey missed out on an Emmy award because it was largely propaganda, a royal expert has claimed. The couple sat down for a tell-all chat with the talk show host in March and made several claims against the royal family. They alleged that there had been conversations about how dark son Archieaposs skin would be, and Meghan claimed she was denied help for her mental health despite having suicidal thoughts. The interview was nominated for a prestigious Emmy award in the Outstanding Hosted Nonfiction Series or Special category, but it was pipped to the post by the documentary Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy. Speaking to the Daily Star, royal expert and film critic Richard Fitzwilliams said he had originally thought it had a very good chance” of winning after it was screened in  countries and had Oprah fronting it.But he added: They were given too easy a le - there wasn’t a single point that Oprah pushed them on. You can see why an awards ceremony would see flaws that the average viewer would not pick up on. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .The fact that it did so well with the audience wouldn’t give it a right to win by itself. Following the airing of the chat earlier in the year, Buckingham Palace issued a statement saying the Queen was saddened by the allegations made by Harry and Meghan, but added that some recollections may y. However, in Finding Freedom, an unauthorised biography of the couple, friends of Harry and Meghan claim the Queen has not taken full ownership of the issues they raised during the Oprah interview.The authors of the updated book also say the statement did not go unnoticed.Meanwhile, Harry is set to appear on TV tonight in a BBC documentary that pays tribute to his late grandfather Prince Philip.The special programme, which also features the Duke of Cambridge, Prince Andrew and Prince Charles, was originally arranged to mark the Dukeaposs th birthday in June, but he sadly died two months before his centenary. Interviews with the royals were recorded both before and after Philipaposs death, with Harryaposs tributes filmed in Calornia where he now lives after quitting the UK. In one clip, Harry talks about his grandfather and grandmotheraposs relationship, calling them the most adorable couple. He says: The two of them together were just the most adorable couple. To me knowing the cheekiness of him and knowing that behind what the world sees you have two iniduals who were very much in love and both, from a very young age, have dedicated their le to service... that is an incredible bond between two people. title: family put house up rent
story: :root Family put house up for rent, pack a campervan and learn on the road in new adventureThe Hennessey Bowers family left their home in Staffordshire for one on the road where they teach their kids from the comfort of a campervan as they travel across EuropeFamily put house up for rent, pack a campervan and learn on the road in new adventure Image: Caters News AgencyBySophie Corcoran:,  Sep | commentsA mum has ditched the classroom and is instead roadschooling her children in a campervan. Kate Hennessey Bowersapos classroom camper comes compete with its own mini library and white board. She has been homeschooling her children Edith, , and Clarence, , with her husband Danny for two years. However, more recently, the family decided to move out of their five-bedroom house in Staffordshire and into a mini bus, which they have converted into a home and school. Their children now learn while travelling around Europe, in what has been dubbed roadschooling. Kate and Danny say they often hold lessons on location including in the woods, on the beach, at a museum or in their own teepee tent. They are renting out their old home after buying and refurbishing the campervan at a cost of around £,. What do you think of their decision  Do you fancy an adventure like this  Have your say in the comments  The van also features a table which acts as a school desk. It has lots of storage for learning resources such as workbooks, Lego, journals, crafting kits, board games, maps and jigsaws and can be put away while they are driving. Kate, , said: Itaposs something we have been intending to do for quite a while. Itaposs still early days but so far itaposs what I expected really. There are highs and lows and niggles but equally it can be so serene at times. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter We now live very frugally but itaposs a very rewarding way to live. We had to de-clutter and get rid of a lot of things, but that process has been going on for a while now. With regards to toys, we have had a one in, one out system for some time, so for every new toy that comes in they donate an old one to charity.  Due to lockdowns people assume homeschooling means not mixing with other children but in my experience, it is actually more sociable than mainstream school. We have a really busy schedule, staying in campsites run by other home educators and doing activities and things with other children and families all the time.  It definitely gives the kids a deeper connection with themselves and also with nature and the community too. They arenapost learning about history from a text book, instead we go to visit the castle itself and learn that way. Cooking has become much more basic, itaposs all one pot meals really but we also have an outdoor fire pit which is useful. Of course, we miss our friends and family back home but they do come to visit. Edith sometimes says she misses her old bedroom, I think she probably had the biggest bedroom in the house, but they are enjoying this new adventure just as much as us and we canapost wait to see where it takes us. title: future tech sector uk woefully
story: :root Future will be all about tech sector but UK woefully under preparing its childrenDigital skills have never been more important to todays children, andwe dont act now, employment for future generations looks bleak, says Eva SimpsonCourses to teach my video game enthusiast to code or to get into tech are ludicrously expensiveImage: GettyopinionByEva Simpson:,  Sep | commentsAsk my six-year-old what he wants to be when he grows up and, without ­hesitation, he’ll bark “I want to make video games”. I’ve lost count of the times he’s told me that school’s “boooorring” and he wants to go to video game school which would be way more fun. If I’m honest, it’s an ­ambition I’d half hoped he’d grow out of, but after attending a tech event this week, I realise he’s more clued up about the future of work than I am.London Tech Week brings together some of the biggest players in the digital field to discuss the state of the industry. The question that kept coming up again and again was what is the UK going to do about its chronic digital skills shortage Do you agree  Have your say in the comment section  The industry agrees immediate and drastic attention is needed. And a recent report by the Department for Culture, Media and Sport revealed there are almost , UK jobs currently vacant that require data skills. There was also an unanimous plea for the education system to put technology at the heart of the curriculum. From where I’m sitting, that certainly doesn’t appear to be happening. My eldest son took and then quickly dropped out of GCSE computing while courses to teach my video game enthusiast to code or to get into tech are ludicrously expensive. If the pandemic taught us anything, it’s that the future will be all about the tech sector, and at the moment, we are woefully under preparing our children for what lies ahead. Tech has its own PR problem. Too many young people think tech is only for kids that are good at maths and science. The technologists I met on Monday assured me that is far from the truth. There are jobs for people with so many dferent skill sets and the sooner young people are introduced to the sector the easier it will be for them to land one. The UK is by no means the only country facing challenges in this area, but it’s lagging behind countries like the US, Singapore, Sweden and Denmark. Coincidentally Sebastian Siemiatkowski, the Swedish founder of tech firm Klarna, revealed he got his first computer from a government scheme. Before he was dumped as education secretary, Gavin Williamson decided one of his key ­objectives to help make society more equal for state school children was to learn Latin. He even sank £million into a pilot scheme for  UK schools. Doesn’t this show just how out of touch our education system is on this  There was certainly consensus from industry movers and shakers that schools and teachers must adapt to the needs of the tech industry. If not, the repercussions for future generations don’t bear thinking about. title: happy bright teen took life
story: :root Happy and bright teen took her own le after being given acne drug, inquest toldAnnabel Wright, , took her own le several months after being prescribed Roaccutane by a dermatologist and are convinced there is a link between the acne drug and her deathAnnabel Wright was taking Roaccutane for her acne when she diedByMark BranaganRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Sep | commentsThe parents of a schoolgirl who took her own le believe her death was linked to acne medication she had been put on months before, an inquest heard. Annabel Wright, , was found dead in her bedroom just  minutes after chatting to her dad Simon Wright, with her family adamant she was not bothered by her skin condition and was happy before taking Roaccutane. Mum Helen Wright told the hearing on Wednesday she had not requested for her daughter to be switched from antibiotics and had read about two US teens who had died by suicide while on the acne medication. Annabel began taking the new prescription - in the form of Isotretinoin capsules - nine months before her death at the age of , after being referred by her GP to a dermatologist. Mrs Wright, , said her daughter was performing well at St Davidaposs School in Harrogate, Yorkshire, adding nothing ever bothered her.Have you been affected by this story  Let us know at webnews@mirror On July  , Mrs Wright and her daughter attended Church Lane Surgery in Boroughbridge for a routine review of her medication. She had suffered from acne since the age of  and had been on lymecycline antibiotics for a year. At the consultation, Mrs Wright said the GP, whom they had not seen before, referred Annabel to a dermatologist at Harrogate District Hospital, something the family had not asked for. The mum said they had not expected it as the teenaposs skin looked to be getting better, but they were pleased to be potentially coming off antibiotics. A letter from the GP - read out in the inquest - stated Annabelaposs skin was not improving, something her mum did not agree with but she took her for the hospital appointment on October   regardless. The consultant said she wanted the teenager on Roaccutane before she got any scarring, explained Mrs Wright. She was only  and it panicked her, she said. The family were given a leaflet which Annabel ticked boxes on and her mother signed. There was a warning that a number of side effects may occur but there are extremely rare. Mrs Wright said: There is nothing in there about suicide. Annabel was not depressed. I was told only children depressed about their skin might take their own lives.  When you sit opposite an expert in their field and they say aposYes, but it could be argued that these children were depressed about their acne - it sways you. I was not aware that sudden suicidal impulses could overcome a perfectly normal person. At the end of January , Mrs Wright noticed scratches on her daughteraposs wrists and she admitted she had begun self-harming. She said she just felt low. She could not explain why, her mum added. Mr Wright, , told the court he gave her a stern talking to about the risks of self-harming, followed by some love and affection. There were no other signs anything was wrong, the court heard. Mrs Wright agreed with the hospital reports that Annabelaposs treatment was progressing well and she hardly had any spots at all except while on monthly cycle. It was discussed that Annabel could switch to hyfication, a surgical procedure for removing lesions, but this never happened and her mother never asked why. On May , , at the final consultation before her death the same day, Annabel was told the treatment had been so successful her dosage would be reduced the next day. She was concerned this might cause the acne to , but she was reassured by her mum. The same evening, Annabel had a normal meal with her family before going up to her room to revise for a Spanish test. Her mother, grandmother, and  year old brother then went off to a young farmeraposs do. They asked Annabelshe wanted to come but she declined. Mr Wright came home later that evening and chatted to his daughter before she went to her room. He said: I would have noticedshe was crying or upset. It was just a nothing. When the rest of the family came home, Annabelaposs grandmother went upstairs to check on her and immediately called for Mr Wright. He said: I knew something was wrong. I ran upstairs. She was hanging there. I tried my best to resuscitate her. My son who was  at the time helped me. Askedthey believed there was a link between the acne medication and the daughteraposs death, both parents were convinced there was. Mrs Wright said: Absolutely. Normal, happy people do not just commit suicide without any sign or lead up to it. I have also been in touch with several other families who have lost children to this drug. There were no other injuries and toxicology tests for drugs and alcohol proved negative, the corners court in Northallerton, North Yorkshire, was told. The hearing continues.* If youaposre struggling and need to talk, the Samaritans operate a free helpline open   on  . Alternatively, you can email jo@samaritans.org or visit their site to find your local branch. You matter.Comment MORE ON EducationHospitalsSchoolsMental healthTeenagersPrescriptionsBullyingInquests" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: harry meghan cant wait first
story: :root Harry and Meghan cant wait for first-ever trip to New York together in romantic fallPrince Harry and Meghan Markle will be making an appearance at the Global Citizen Live event in New York on Saturday, and friends have said they cant wait to explore the cityPrince Harry and Meghan Markle, who will be visiting New York City this weekend Image: PAByJenner Newton:,  Sep | commentsPrince Harry and Meghan Markle are set to take their first-ever trip to New York City together at the weekend. The couple will make their first joint public appearance since the birth of their daughter Lilibet in June at the -hour star-studded global TV event Global Citizen Live in Central Park. And according to friends, they canapost wait to explore the Big Apple with one another in the romantic fall, reports Page Six. Itaposs also reported that Meghan and Harry will be making the trip to New York alone with their children two-year-old Archie and three-month-old Lilibet staying at home in Calornia.  Their trip to the city will see them appear at Global Citizen Live to continue their urgent work with world leaders in the pursuit of global vaccine equity to end the COVID- pandemic for everyone, everywhere. The event organisers also call them two of the strongest voices on vaccine equity.Both Harry and Meghan have spoken out about vaccine equity in the past and in May, Harry made an appearance at Vax Live - a concert in Calornia to promote the sharing of vaccines.Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up .The couple has also previously written an open letter to the chief executives of pharmaceutical companies like Pfizer, Moderna and AstraZeneca urging them to redouble their support for the UN-sponsored Covax programme. Their appearance at the event also will mark Meghanaposs first public engagement since Lilibet was born on June .Since then she has only been seen in photos, such as the coupleaposs TIME magazine shoot published last week, and in a video to mark her th birthday in August.  Meghan was last in New York in early September , when she travelled to the city to support her friend Serena Williams in the US Open at Flushing Meadow. Harryaposs last trip there was in  when he toured areas devastated by Hurricane Sandy. The coupleaposs trip to New York comes after they were named in TIME magazineaposs  most influential people in .  The magazine praised the pair for having compassion for the people they donapost know, adding: They donapost just opine. They run towards the struggle. Harry and Meghan, who say they are humbled to be on the list, appear in the new issue of the magazine alongside a short profile of them by chef José Andrés, a founder of the World Central Kitchen charity. He told TIME : Springing into action is not the easy choice for a young duke and duchess who have been blessed through birth and talent, and burned by fame. It would be much safer to enjoy their good fortune and stay silent.That’s not what Harry and Meghan do, or who they are. They turn compassion into boots on the ground through their Archewell Foundation. They give voice to the voiceless through media production. Hand in hand with nonprofit partners, they take risks to help communities in need—offering mental-health support to Black women and girls in the U.S., and feeding those affected by natural disasters in India and the Caribbean. title: home remote scottish island just
story: :root Home on remote Scottish island with just  people could be yours for £,A home on the remote Isle of Eigg,  miles off the coast of Scotland, needs a new occupant who is willing to fully immerse themselves in island le, alongside the  other residentsFancy living off grid  This Shepherds hut could be yours for £, Image: The Isle of Eigg Heritage TrustByKate Buck:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsIf youaposve ever wanted to escape the hustle and bustle of everyday le, then this could be the perfect opportunity. A home on the remote Isle of Eigg,  miles off the coast of Scotland, is a single room building needing a new occupant who is willing to fully immerse themselves in island le, alongside the  other residents. The converted shepherdaposs building, named Sandamhor Bothy, will need a lot of TLC and some extensive renovations, but is currently on the market for £, and comes with some land to boot. The island is owned by the Isle of Eigg Heritage Trust who have managed it since a community buyout in . Ownership of Eigg was transferred to the islanders in a deal that saw £.m in funds raised.  The Trust has responsibility for stewardship of the island, its buildings and natural heritage, and for supporting future development. Prospective buyers have now been offered viewings of the bothy and a chance to live on Eigg on a full time basis. A sales brochure says: The plot enjoys easterly views across the seascape towards the Scottish mainland. Access is via a shared unsurfaced and rough access track. The building is stone built and contains a single room ided by a low wall. Water is supplied to an inside sink and outside toilet. There is currently a cast iron wood-burning stove installed in the property. The plot is subject to rules stopping it being used as a holiday or second home. Applications to buy the bothy will be closed on November . About five miles long by three miles wide, Eigg lies  miles off the Scottish west coast, south of the Isle of Skye. The island has a fascinating history, superb wildle and a vibrant community. The main industries on Eigg are tourism, agriculture, public services, construction and the creative industries. More than  years ago, every resident of Eigg, barring one elderly woman, was killed during a clan feud. Islanders, who were members of the Macdonald clan, were murdered by a raiding party of Macleods from Skye. The islanders had been hiding in a cave for three days when they were discovered. Macleods blocked the narrow entrance to their hideout with heather and other vegetation before setting the material alight. The Macdonalds were suffocated by smoke and their bodies left in the cave. It is believed that the massacre happened in or around the year . title: how book covid booster jab
story: :root How to book a Covid- booster jab – and who’s eligible for one After  million vaccine doses administered across England already, people are now eligible for a Covid- booster jab, providing their most recent jab was six months ago Image: Daily Mirror Andy StenningByBenjamin Lynch:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsCovid- vaccine booster shots are now available. As we continue to recover from the coronavirus pandemic, the NHS insist it is important for people to remain vigilant in the face of the disease and the booster is an important way of fighting it. Similar to the flu booster, the jab will help make immunity to catching or suffering the effects of Covid- far less likely. The NHS say currently that around four in five adults in England have received both doses of the vaccine, with  million doses administered overall since Maggie Keenan received the first dose outside a clinical trial in December . GP and deputy lead for the vaccination programme Dr Nikki Kanani, told NHS England : The vaccines are the best way to protect yourself, your family and friends as we head in to winter when we know Covid can present a bigger risk to our health.Now that the National Booking Service has opened to people eligible for a booster it’s time to book yourself in, it’s the quickest and most convenient way to book your jab in. How do I get my booster and which vaccine will I receive  Letters and text messages are now being circulated as the NHS identies those who meet the criteria for the jab. Once a text has been received, you can use the online service here to book your third jab.You must be registered to a GP. Those who are not able to use the online service should book by phoning . Jabs will be distributed through vaccination centres, GPaposs, pharmacies and hospitals. The boosters will be one of the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines. Those who received the Oxford Astra Zeneca vaccine will still receive either a Moderna or Pfizer booster. There are a few things to watch out for before attempting to book your next jab. There are currently nine priority groups eligible for their booster jab, providing your last jab was over six months ago. Those eligible include all adults over the age of , or those living in residential homes for the elderly. Older people will be contacted first. Frontline health and social care workers are also included. For those aged  to , only people with signicant underlying health conditions will require the jab, as well as the adult points of contact for those with a reduced ability to fight infections, known as the immunosuppressed. If you have tested positive for Covid- recently, you must wait  days before booking, starting from the date you took the test.Comment MORE ON Coronavirus vaccineCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: incredible blind dog who can
story: :root Blind dog that never puts a foot wrong is declared a medical mysteryBorder Collie Dave "never puts a foot wrong" and can even navigate around puddles despite his blindness, his owner said - leaving vets completely baffled by his conditionDave the border collie with owner Jane Downes Image: James Linsell-Clark  SWNSByBen Turner:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsAn incredible dog whose owner didnapost know he was totally blind for an extraordinary nine months has been declared a medical mystery by veterinary experts. Border Collie Dave never puts a foot wrong and can even navigate around puddles despite his blindness - leaving vets completely baffled by his condition. Owner Jane Downes, , said that Dave always comes when called and will happily play with other dogs despite his retinas being completely undeveloped - making him even more remarkable. A top UK vet has declared Dave a medical mystery after confirming that the pooch - believed to be between five to seven years old - is fully blind. Jane, who owned Dave for almost a year before making the discovery, said: No oneaposs got any answers. Itaposs just a conundrum. Itaposs just really strange. Heaposs a blind dog that can see. Maybe itaposs a sixth sense, who knows  He had everyone fooled - even me as his owner I was fooled for nine months. Jane bought Dave from an animal rescue centre in February , when no issues were raised regarding his sight - even after a check-up at the local vet. Jane, from Waterbeach, Cambs, added: He jumped into the back of the car and I brought him home. A couple of people said he had funny eyes but I just thought heaposs got beautul eyes. On a couple of occasions he walked into things but I put that down to him being a sheepdog who more than likely lived in a barn rather than a house. He wouldnapost put a foot wrong. He would come back when you called him.  But in December, Dave stumbled over a step at a pet shop in Cambridge, where the owner suggested to Jane that her dog might be blind. She took Dave to a specialist vet, where they finally discovered that he was totally blind and his retinas had never developed, meaning he was sightless from birth. After the revelation, Jane called on the help of Cambridge Universityaposs David Williams, a top veterinary ophthalmologist, who organised two obstacle course challenges for Dave and a retina test, which confirmed the diagnosis. He told a local newspaper: I see a lot of blind dogs and they all bump into objects in a way that Dave didnapost - so at present he is a medical mystery! Just because Iaposve been doing this for  years, it doesnapost mean Iaposve seen everything, and this I canapost explain.  In le you like to think you know everything, but thataposs not always the case. Dave now enjoys running around at home with his new brother Sammy, a two-year-old Border Collie, who joined the family in October last year. Jane, who lives with husband Mick, , said that Dave lives a happy and full le. She explained: He goes straight to his food. He chases other dogs around even though he canapost see them. He can jump into the boot of my car. He walks around puddles. On the very rare occasion, he walks into something he just shrugs it off and carries on. Daveaposs only limit is his fear of going into the sea - but Dave doesnapost knowthis is due to his blindness or a possible traumatic experience as a puppy. title: inside creepy time capsule home
story: :root Inside creepy time capsule home left empty for decade after owners mysteriously vanishLucys house has been left abandoned for more than a decade after the occupants mysteriously vanished - leaving their beds still made, lights turned on and their clothes hanging in the wardrobeUnsettling pictures of a perfectly preserved abandoned -year-old house have ben shared, leaving questions as to who left the home behind. Image: Triangle NewsByLottie Tiplady-BishopKate Buck:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep Unsettling pictures of a perfectly preserved -year-old house have been shared, sparking questions as to who left it behind. The home lies in the picturesque setting of Tallington, Lincolnshire, but was abandoned over  years ago - leaving nature to slowly reclaim the building. Ivy now grows up the walls and covers almost the entire property, blanketing what was left inside in a shroud of mystery. The super-tidy house is rumoured to have once been home to a little girl known only as Lucy, and clues to her name have been left all over place. However there are no clues as to why the home has been left empty for so long. It still has beds neatly made up, lights left on and lonely looking toys in its nursery. Previous urban explorers who have visited the home have reported the electric toothbrushes still having charge. One visitor, who wished to remain anonymous, explained: Lucyaposs house is sort of an urban legend, hardly anyone has ever gotten inside as itaposs hidden and watched by angry neighbours. Itaposs rumoured that it was once a happy family home to Lucy and her parents until her mother vanished one night and never came home. Lucy remained in the house with her dad until they too just left one day and never came back. There are still clothes hanging up in the wardrobe and toothbrushes in the bathroom. Parts are starting to decay and fall down but itaposs a real mystery. What happened to Lucy  Itaposs bizarre stuff. The haunting snaps show rows of shirts neatly hung up in the wardrobe and an articial plant neatly positioned in the once spotless conservatory - which is now water-stained and rotting. In what may once have been Lucyaposs bedroom, twin beds are neatly made up with cute pink sheets and a framed picture of teddies and toys adorn the polka-dot walls. In the corner, a forlorn-looking teddy bear stares longingly out of the window, perching on a rocking chair that hasnapost moved in a decade. In the family bathroom, toothbrushes, a razor and deodorant can be seen left somewhat haphazardly around the sink, which is still sparkling clean, save for a thin layer of dust. An ancient computer sits in the messy study, and in another bedroom a row of sad-looking teddies sit, alone, in an empty cot. A trendy black ball gown hangs on the back of one of the bedroom doors, never to be worn again. Family photos adorn the mantlepiece of the property, alongside a wooden ornament fashioned into the word aposLucyapos. The outside of the home has been overgrown with trees and shrubbery, with nature forcing its way through some of the homeaposs windows where ivy can be seen creeping across sills and down walls.Most ReadDont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON ViralHome Tour" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: inside eerie abandoned grandmas house
story: :root Inside the eerie abandoned ‘grandma’s house’ left untouched for decadesItems appear to be perfectly preserved despite being left to collect dust for decades, with books still left on the shelves and an old TV in seemingly perfect conditionWoman finds time capsule of old photos in abandoned grandmas houseByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Sep | commentsAn abandoned house which has sat untouched and left to rot for decades has been rediscovered, containing within its doors “priceless” antiques and eerie old photographs. An urban explorer, known as Urbex Muse, revealed her findings after wandering the home which she has dubbed “grandma’s house”.Items appear to be perfectly preserved despite being left to collect dust for decades, with books still left on the shelves and an old TV in seemingly perfect condition, according to the Daily Star. On the coffee table, there appears to be a tray with cutlery and a plate left out assomeone had just finished their dinner before the house was abandoned.A suitcase containing black and white photos of what appears to be weddings and servicemen from around World War One were also shown on Urbex Muse’s Instagram page. One photo appears to be of a triple wedding while another shows a handsome headshot of a man in a soldier’s unorm. The man in the unorm can also be seen in other pictures with a young woman, leading viewers to speculate he was the husband of the previous owner of the house. There also appears to be packets of unprocessed camera film left inside the suitcase.  This home was once bursting at the seams with memories of the old couple that resided here, Urbex Muse wrote in a caption alongside the images of the home. These reminders lingered in every corner, from the nicknacks they collected to the priceless antiques left behind. We even stumbled across grandmas original zucchini bread recipe, which I ended up making and can confirm is amazing.”  Social media users described the atmosphere of the home as “peaceful” and “heart-breaking”. One person commented: “The vibes in these abandoned granny houses is always so peaceful, you can feel the love and good memories tinged with the sadness that the family has left it all behind for whatever reason.” Another added: It kind of broke my heart to see everything left like that. Frozen in time. Like what happened  One event led up to them just leaving their home like that. Defiantly very cool. Thank you for respecting their home.”  A third said: It breaks my heart to think of the history and people that lived in these houses, home is something, like so intimate and full of personality, and then when the person is gone it turns into nothing, just a bunch of pieces in time and space.” Others askedthe explorer could try and find out what happened to the owners of the property. One person wrote: “Are you allowed to take things from abandoned places. like all those pics to find the right owner of them ” Another added: This is so sad, I have tons of pictures from my family even though I never met any of them, but we try to keep the stories that go to each picture so that it be passed down. news uk-news judge-rinders-french-bulldog-passes-"Judge Rinders dog Rocco farts on TVByBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsJudge Robert Rinder’s French bulldog, Rocco, was in the doghouse after passing wind in the courtroom - but the audience found it hilarious. The celebrity judge was hearing a case which saw Layla bring her friend, Louise, to court to claim money owed for a chihuahua she sold to her. Louise had agreed to pay £, for Rolo the chihuahua, but failed to do so, resulting in a breakdown in the friendship. They appeared in Judge Rinderaposs courtroom on the show on Monday, where the case was outlined. The puppy had been a gt to Layla from her boyfriend, James, but after realising the amount of time and attention the pup needed, alongside caring for a newborn, she decided to rehome him.  The -year-old said: “People who don’t have dogs might not really understand it, but when you’ve emotionally bonded with an animal and you decide that it’s not working, to let them go, what’s that like ” Layla described it like giving up a child and was determined to find him a home he deserved, selling him to friend Louise for £,. Judge Rinder was introduced to Rolo and gave him a cuddle, saying: “I can see why you fell in love. He’s charming, he doesn’t answer back, he’s always affectionate and I suspect he’s more rational than most partners.” He went on to askhis French bulldog Rocco could offer his opinion on the chihuahua, and had a member of the team bring his pet from his chambers into the courtroom. TeamDogs is a community for dog lovers who want to get the most out of their relationship with their best pal. Make sharing the cutest photos of your dog your first job on the website and after youaposve done that, leave a tip to help fellow dog owners live their best lives as a proud pooch parent. Search through hundreds of recommended walks, treats, toys and places to stay when youaposre on an adventure together. From dog-friendly pubs to product reviews and the latest news, you can snf it all out at TeamDogs. As Judge Rinder bent down to pull Rocco onto his lap, he exclaimed: “Oh dear, he’s just farted terribly.” The comment sent the audience into a fit of giggles as he added: “It’s where I get it from, I can smell a liar like a fart in a kennel.” He went on to explain that he oversees numerous court cases which include dogs, which are classed as property in law. He said: “The idea that anyone who owns a pet and is a good pet owner feels about their dog as property is a very stupid thing.” Meanwhile, Rocco let out a yawn to which his owner asked: “Am I boring you ” The Frenchie sat on the judges lap waiting patiently for a verdict, wearing his own court bib.  Louise was ordered to pay Layla the £, for Rolo the chihuahua and said: “£,, which is cheap for the price of friendship, isn’t that right ” Rocco let out a small grunt much to the courtaposs amusement as Judge Rinder and Rocco made their way back to chambers. But it wasn’t the first time that Rocco has showed up his dog dad on set. In fact, on spin-off show Judge Rinder’s Kids Courtroom, Rocco even pooped in the judges lap.As he listened to a pair of brothers argue over a bad snoring habit, the judge fell silent before erupting into laughter at- the fact Rocco, who had an upset stomach, had done a poo on his lap.Comment MORE ON TeamDogsAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: junior doctor who worked covid
story: :root Junior doctor who worked on Covid frontline found dead after night swim with friendsThirushika Sathialingam, , was found dead on Margate seafront after a late-night swim with colleaguesTributes have been paid to Dr Thirushika SathialingamByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Sep | commentsA junior doctor who worked on the Covid frontline died after going for a late-night swim with friends. Thirushika Sathialingam, known as Thiru to her friends, was found dead on Margate seafront in the early hours of Saturday September . She is understood to have gone swimming with colleagues, who sounded the alarm after noticing she was missing when they ed to their accommodation. A major search was launched at am involving leboat crews, police, firefighters and a coastguard rescue helicopter, and her body was discovered by RNLI volunteers a few hours later. Thiru, , had been working at the Queen Elizabeth The Queen Mother Hospitalalongside her brother, Kaushaliyan, who is also a junior doctor. Kaushaliyan said: I donapost think many siblings were as close as we were. We did almost everything together.  She was a fantastic doctor. I donapost think she realised how good she was, but it came naturally to her. She was able to think outside the box to get things done for her patients, and she loved that medicine was such a complex subject. She was interested in anaesthetics because she enjoyed the scientic approach to it. She wanted to be able to do procedures that would make a real dference to people. Thiru was aspiring to follow in her father’s footsteps and become a consultant anaesthetist at the hospital.  Her father Sathialingam, who retired from the hospital in July, said she was “passionate” about her work and “always had time to listen to people”. He said: “During the second wave of Covid she was on a respiratory ward with people who had the virus and she would sit and talk to them, holding their hands to give them comfort.” She was also a talented dancer, performing classical Indian routines at charity events and teaching others. She loved travelling and would meticulously plan trips around the world and the UK. Her boyfriend, Peter Speilbichler, who she had met while studying medicine at Riga Stradins University in Latvia, said: I have had calls from my friendsapos parents who only met her once or twice, saying how amazing she was and how she lit up the room and made everyone welcome. If there was someone who was not part of a group, she would make sure she spoke to them and that they were included and felt comfortable. She could get on with everyone and she was always kind and smiling. I never heard anything malicious come out of her mouth, evenshe was angry. The time we spent together was amazing and I loved everything about her. East Kent Hospitalsapos chief executive Susan Acott said her death as a huge loss to the Trust, adding that she was a “real shining star” who was known for her “caring nature” and passion for her patients. She continued: “It is clear she would have had a bright future ahead of her and I have no doubt she had the potential to achieve anything she set her heart on.” Comment MORE ON IlfordQueen Elizabeth The Queen MotherHospitalsRoyal FamilyMental health" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: man 28 snatches baby girl
story: :root Man, , snatches baby girl from play area, assaults woman and drives offPolice say they chased down a -year-old man after he snatched the infant from a play area in Crawley town centre on Monday afternoonIgnoring pleas tothe child, the -year-old man snatched the one-year-old away from the Memorial Gardens, Crawley, Sussex Image: Alamy Stock PhotoByAnna GladwinRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Sep A -year-old man assaulted a woman as he snatched a one-year-old baby girl from a playground and drove off with her, police say. The man and woman - who are known to each other - were with the infant in the play area of Memorial Gardens park in Crawley town centre, West Sussex. The man grabbed the youngster and ignored the womanaposs pleas toher during the incident between  and .pm on Monday.With the child in his arms, he walked towards the car park while pushing the woman away, Sussex Live reports.He then drove off at speed without securing the child in the car properly, police say.  Police were informed and pursued the car to the nearby West Green area - around a mile-and-a-half away - where it stopped. The child and woman were unharmed and are receiving support from specially trained officers. The -year-old man was arrested on suspicion of making threats to kill, common assault, dangerous driving and possessing an offensive weapon. After being interviewed he was released on police bail until October  while enquiries continue.Detective Constable Penny Furtado of the West Sussex Safeguarding Investigations Unit said If you were in the Memorial Gardens area that afternoon and saw what happened, please contact us either online or by calling , quoting serial  of  . title: man tells sister shes not
story: :root Man tells sister she’s not good enough at maths to join the police - the internet disagreesThe woman asked the Reddit thread ‘AITA’she was in the wrong for being brutally honest to her sisterReddit users were quick to call out the man on his blunt behaviour Image: GettyByEmily Sleight:,  Sep | commentsEveryone has a dream job, but imagine being told by your own brother that youaposre not clever enough for it because you can’t do maths. Would it be classed as a firm but fair comment, or is it just plain mean A man has posted his story on the Reddit thread ‘AITA’ which is where the internet decides whether you’re in the right or wrong.He said: “So Iaposmcurrently serving in the metropolitan police, been serving for a good few years. Recently my sisterwants to join the Scottish Police. “Now, my sister is currently a marketing executive but she says that itaposs her dream to serve. “However she was in the lowest math class in primary and high school, so I told her that she would fail it because of her problem with math. She hasnapost talked to me since.” And it seems that not only has his comment angered his sister but the internet as well with many Reddit users insisting dubbing it cruel and unnecessary. On the Reddit forum, users can decide whether they agree with the original poster or not by using a list of acronyms.Maths-Whizz is a super clever virtual maths tutor which delivers interactive games, lessons and exercises for five to  year olds.To see how good it is at transforming home learning for parents, weaposve negotiated an exclusive % off price to make it £. for the first month.Seeyou like it first and sign up to a -day no-obligation free trial by clicking here. If you want to sign up for a month at a time or even a year, you can do that here but donapost forget to use the promo code aposMATHSapos.  For reference, here is the key for AITA: Youaposre the a** hole YTA Youaposre Not the a** hole NTA Everyone sucks here  ESH No a** holes here  NAH Not enough info  INFO One peeved user responded to his thread saying: “YTA - You could have offered to help her study for the math portion of the test. aposHey sis, the math portion of the test is kind of dficult, I can help you studyyou want apos “Instead you cut her down. Not cool at all, dude.” Another said: “YTA. Your comment was cruel and unnecessary. Many cruel people use aposwell I was just being honestapos. This seems like one of those situations. “What do you think will be worse for her - following her dreams and failing or knowing her family thinks she’s too stupid and never trying  “I cannot see any kind intentions in your comment. If there was a scale of a**holery on this sub from - I’d put you at a solid  for what you said and for the one follow up comment you’ve left so far.” - ouch. Since uploading the thread, the man edited his post and said: “I had a look at all the comments and realised that I was an absolute d***! “I was just worried she would become our brothershe was rejected, Iaposve been told that itaposs basic maths in the Scottish Police, so Iaposm no longer as worried and Iaposll be supporting her.” At least he sort of learnt his lesson then. title: mcdonalds worker pours coca cola
story: :root McDonalds worker pours Coca-Cola on homeless man leaving him in tearsThe McDonalds employee emptied Coca-Cola on his head outside of a branch in Birkenhead, but locals were quick to help the manThe incident occurred the McDonalds drive-through branch at The Rock Retail Park in Birkenhead, Merseyside Image: GoogleByDanny RiggShiler Mahmoudi:,  Sep | commentsA homeless man who allegedly had a drink poured on him by a McDonaldaposs worker has been left in tears.The incident is said to have occurred next to the McDonaldaposs drive-through branch at The Rock Retail Park in Birkenhead, Merseyside, the Liverpool Echo reports.It is alleged that the employee emptied Coca Cola on the manaposs head, leaving him emotionally distressed. A passer-by, Tracy Martinedale, was fuming to learn what happened when she arrived at around am on Tuesday  September. She saw the distraught man In tears as he informed the duty manager of the chain of what had happened.  Tracy, , said: Itaposs so bad. You donapost do that to another human being, whether theyaposre beggars or not. You just donapost. I was fuming. After speaking to the homeless man good-Samaritan Tracy went to buy new clothes for him from a local charity shop.  But Koala Charity Shop Claughton manager Mandy Edwards decided to give the coat, trousers, jumper and top to her for free. Mandy, , told the Echo : I said aposNo, itaposs fine to just take themapos, because thataposs awful what they did to him. So we donated the clothes and said, aposjust take them, thataposs fineapos. Theyaposre trying to keep their dignity, and then someone throws a thing of Coca Cola all over them. Itaposs awful, isnapost it  Describing the homeless manaposs reaction to the clothes, Tracy said: He was nearly crying. Oh my god, he couldnapost believe that somebody was doing that for him. It was what he needed at the time. A spokesperson for McDonald’s told the ECHO: We are aware of this allegation and are investigating this as a matter of urgency. title: mum 39 who blamed back
story: :root Mum, , who blamed back pain on working from sofa diagnosed with deadly sepsisLouise Carter, , was admitted to Scunthorpe General Hospital in August last year while experiencing extreme pain which developed into vomiting, hallucinations and feverMum-of-three Louise Carter, , initially feared her bad back was caused by lying on the sofa to type Image: Kennedy News and MediaByRebecca CooleyRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Sep | comments A mum who blamed her back pain on sitting on the sofa while working from home was later diagnosed with sepsis. Louise Carter, , from Gilberdyke, East Yorkshire, says she begged doctors to test her for sepsis after self-diagnosing her symptoms on Google.The mum-of-three had been experiencing back pain, which she dismissed as discomfort from sitting on the sofa to type during lockdown. But, in August last year she was rushed to Scunthorpe General Hospital when she could no longer handle the searing pain. She was unable to urinate and soon started vomiting, hallucinating, and running a high fever. After several days without answers, the social worker Googled her symptoms and became convinced she had sepsis. The le-threatening ailment is caused by the immune system damaging body tissue while trying to react to an infection. Despite crying and begging doctors to test her for blood poisoning, she claims they refused and denied any possibility of her having the illness. Fearing she survived a close call with death, Louise has spoken out to alert others to sepsis symptoms, and to urge people to follow their gutthey think they have it. She said: I had really bad back pain and thought it was because of working from home during the pandemic and sitting on the sofa typing all day. I could barely move because of the pain and couldnapost go to the toilet either so I rang my doctor and he told me to ring an ambulance. They took me to AE in Scunthorpe Hospital. I was really poorly and out of it. After a couple of days of being in hospital I started projectile vomiting, having hallucinations and was shivering but sweating at the same time. I told the doctor I think itaposs sepsis and she said itaposs not, she said my blood pressure was normal but I asked her to check my stats again.I was furious and crying because I knew something was wrong. I had to push for them to test me for sepsis and keep telling them that I had all the symptoms. They did more bloods and the next morning two doctors came to see me and said it was sepsis. The mum-of-three spent two and a half weeks in hospital fighting the deadly condition and dealing with terrying symptoms. Thinking she was on her death bed, she asked for her three children Connor, , Kiah, , and Kadi,  to be allowed to visit despite Covid- restrictions on visitors at the time.  Louise said: When I went to AE they just put a catheter in because they thought it was something wrong with my bladder as I couldnapost wee. I started being sick and didnapost eat or drink for a few days. Iaposm not ever sick even when Iaposve drank too much. I have an iron stomach, so I knew something wasnapost right. Then I started having hallucinations - I saw one of my dead friends and a nurse peeping round the curtains in the room but the healthcare worker kept telling me no one was there. It was really scary. I was crying and askingsomething was wrong with me. They shouldaposve recognised that I had the symptoms and done a blood culture test straight away.  When they told me I had sepsis I askedit was a good idea to get my family to visit me because I know how serious sepsis is and they said yes - I thought it must be badthey will let me have visitors during the pandemic. Louise made a full recovery after being treated with antibiotics but fears it could have turned out dferentlyshe hadnapost pushed doctors to test her. She had to use a Zimmer frame for a week after leaving hospital because of struggling to walk from the back pain she suffered but this soon passed once she fully recovered from her ordeal. The mum now hopes to raise awareness about the deadly condition and to encourage more people to speak up when they believe their symptoms arenapost being acknowledged. Louise said: I feel really lucky to have not even lost a fingertip or anything because people pass away or lose limbs from sepsis. Itaposs really important to raise awareness about sepsis because it affects so many people but thereaposs not much out there about it. Iaposm nearly  and I didnapost know the symptoms until I Googled them and realised I had it. If you believe you have sepsis you need to push to get blood cultures done. A spokesperson for the Northern Lincolnshire and Goole NHS Foundation Trust said: “Timely treatment of patients with Sepsis is vital so we make sure all patients showing symptoms are screened. In cases like this where patients are staying in hospital they are monitored regularly and,any changes are noted, our staff can take action quickly to start treatment so they can recover fully. We would invite this patient to contact our PALS teamthey have any concerns about their care and treatment so we can discuss it directly with them. title: mum asks shes mad send
story: :root Mum asksshes mad to send her kids to bed fully-clothed to save timeA mum wants to get her children ready for school the night before because she struggles with the time sensitive morning routine – but she’s worried her idea is ‘mad’The mum heard about the time-saving tip online, but wanted a second opinion Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByJess FlahertyZahna Eklund:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsIf you’re not a morning person, pulling yourself out of bed to get ready to face the day can be a real chore – and it’s even more of a struggleyou have young children to help get ready too. That’s why one mum has considered getting her children dressed for the day ahead before they go to bed, but she’s worried her thought process is “mad”.According to the Liverpool Echo, the mum posted to Mumsnet about her dilemma, where she explained she has four children – two of whom have additional needs – and that getting them all ready for school each morning is a nightmare.She wrote: “I have four children. Oldest two have additional needs, so need a lot of help with dressing in the mornings, which can take a long time. Younger two just need help due to their age.  Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. “The mornings are hectic, and between getting myself and the four of them ready, it can take a very long time to get out of the house! “We also need to get a bus, so we miss it sometimes when we haven’t got out on time .” To try and help with her plight, the woman referred to a news article she had read about another mum who dresses her children the night before, and said she considered following that woman’s advice. She added: “I read a news article a little while ago about a woman who says she dresses her children for school the night before! Now I know people will just say go to bed earlier, but my oldest doesn’t sleep at night so we are currently awaiting a referral for a paediatrician. “Am I being unreasonable to consider what this woman does  Would anyone do this  Or am I mad to consider it ” The mum was met with hundreds of responses from other Mumsnet users, many of whom told her it was “gross” to send her kids to school in clothes they had slept in. One person wrote: “No. Theyaposd be so uncomfortable to start with. They will also smell. Not washing in the morning or changing out of clothes they may have sweated in overnight. “It just isn’t a solution. You need to get up earlier.” While another said: No, normal people donapost do this. Iaposm afraid this is definitely not the solution to your morning problems . Someone  tried to be more helpful with their comment, as they wrote: What do you already do - what’s the routine  Posters can help troubleshoot. “I don’t think I could send my children to school in slept-in clothes and I think it doesn’t give them good habits to build off for the future - plusthey mentioned sleeping in their clothes I’m sure school would log that as a concern. And after reading through some comments, the mum insisted she wouldn’t be going through with the plan to send her kids to bed fully clothed. She said: I’m not going to do it, I was just desperate to make the mornings easier but I will try some of these ideas. “Thanks for the supportive comments I am reading them and taking the advice on board. “The oldest is  and she does not sleep till  or am most nights. She shouts, screams, gets out of bed and wonders around – my youngest cannot share a room with her because she is aggressive, so my four-year-old is still in my bed. “None of us get much sleep because she keeps the other ones up with her noise, so my other children aren’t going to bed till late either as they are repeatedly being woken up. She doesn’t struggle to get out of bed, she seems to cope fine on her limited sleep, but it’s the others who struggle where they have been kept up all night. title: mum who became obese due
story: :root Size  mum who became obese due to £-a-week lunch habit drops  dress sizesAmy weighed st lb at her heaviest and went from a size  to a size  in a matter of months. But after ditching the daily lunch dates, she has dropped seven dress sizes and now weighs st lbAmy has dropped seven dress sizes since embarking on her health kick Image: @amys_sw_journeyx   CATERS NEWSByCally Brooks:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA new mum whose weight ballooned after she consumed , calories a day on lunch dates has dropped seven dress sizes. Amy Greaves, , started piling on extra weight after giving birth to her daughter Maia in April . The mum, from Gedling, Nottingham, started meeting other parents for lunch dates while she was on maternity leave, a habit which set her back £-a-month and also caused her waistline to increase. Amy weighed st lb at her heaviest, and went from a size  to a size  in a matter of months. But after ditching the daily lunch dates, she has dropped seven dress sizes and now weighs st lb. Amy, who works as a freelance dance teacher, said it was important for her to look and feel healthy in order to do her job.  Iaposve never been on the smaller side but after giving birth and losing my dad, I turned to food for comfort and would eat my way through maternity,” she said. In January , I decided enough was enough - I was having surgery in March  and I was scared that being overweight would put me at risk of complications. After having Maia, I started going on group playdates with other mums daily and we would eat pub lunches, skip breakfast and have a cake and a coffee in the morning, snack on crisps and chocolate and I made a habit out of eating badly when I was on the go.  She lived in black leggings and baggy t-shirts or jumpers that covered everything up. But one day, she said it clicked. I wanted to be here to see my daughter grow up andI carried on the way I was going, I wouldnapost have been around, she said. The realisation prompted her to join Slimming World and make healthier choices, she said.  Amy has always struggled with her body image after training to be a dancer during her teenage years. She has a history of dieting and putting pressure on herself to look a certain way. You have a warped opinion of yourself - I wish I could go back now and respect my body more and do my training again,” she mused. Now, Amy said she feels like a dferent person much more confident and happier in herself. Iaposm still going to the playdates but I have a completely dferent mindset and donapost need to snack while Iaposm there,” she said. If I get hungry, I make sure to pack some healthy snacks to bring with me rather than eating out.The Mirror is committed to more hopeful news. We recognise the news agenda can sometimes feel overwhelmingly negative.And while itaposs our job to keep you informed and hold those in power to account, we are making a commitment to also report more hopeful news. We will celebrate the people, places and movements that are bringing good into the world and, more than that, we will dig beneath the surface of important issues with the aim of finding hope.We will be firm in our convictions - but always fair-minded. By sharing solutions to problems, we can do more good and feel better about the world around us. Because we believe you deserve it. #mirrormorehopefulFollow on Twitter @mirrormorehope And follow Mirror More Hopeful on Facebook AMYaposS DIET BEFORE: BREAKFAST: Cake and coffee during playdates LUNCH: Sandwich and chips from the pub SNACKS: Chocolate, crisps or anything that was convenient DINNERS: Oven food e.g. chips, pizza, burgers, chicken nuggets AMYaposS DIET NOW: BREAKFAST: Eggs, mushrooms, spinach, bacon, porridge, fruit and yoghurt LUNCH: Omelette, jacket potato, brown bread, low calorie crisps, fruit SNACKS: Meat, fruit, salad, vegetables. story: :root New Covid epicentre revealed as infections spike in  local areas across UKNeath Port Talbot in Wales has the highest rate in the whole of the UK, with , new cases in the seven days to September .Earlier it was revealed cases had shot up by  per cent in a week Image: ANDY RAIN EPA-EFE REX ShutterstockByIan JonesWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  Sep | commentsNearly a quarter of all local areas across the UK have seen a rise in Covid cases, according to the latest figures with a growing cluster of infections in Wales. Of the  local areas across the country have seen a week-on-week rise in infection rates.have seen a fall and two are unchanged, according to data published on Wednesday on the Governmentaposs coronavirus dashboard.Neath Port Talbot in Wales has the highest rate in the whole of the UK, with , new cases in the seven days to September . This is the equivalent of . per , people and is up from . in the seven days to September .  Merthyr Tydfil, also in Wales, has the second highest rate, up from . to ., with  new case. West Dunbartonshire in Scotland has the third highest rate, down from ,. to ., with  new cases. It comes after the government revealed that trials of a new vaccine to fight emerging iants of coronavirus are under way in Manchester. It is hoped the new jab will offer longer-lasting immunity than the current batch. The trials will initially involve participants over the age of  and over and its creators hope it will boost the immune response of first-generation Covid- vaccines to a wide away of iants. title: pregnant teen cell found holding
story: :root Pregnant teen, , found holding dead baby after cries for help ignored for  hoursThe report into the death of the teen prisoner’s baby was published by the Prisons and Probation Ombudsman today, some two years after the tragic event.HMP Bronzefield, where Baby A died Image: TMSByAlice Peacock:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA damning report outlines the failures leading up to the discovery of a teenager holding her dead newborn baby in a prison cell in the largest women’s prison in Europe.Theinvestigation reportinto the death of the teen prisoner’s baby was published by the Prisons and Probation Ombudsman today, two years after the horror incident in September , at HMP Bronzefield in Ashford, Middlesex.According toreports, the baby’s death triggered  separate inquiries. A summary of the case outlines the timeline of ‘Miss A’s’ pregnancy, from when she found out she was pregnant whilst in police custody, in February of  to when she was remanded to HMP Bronzefield, on  August . Shortly after her arrival in the cells a midwe in prison determined that Ms A was  weeks pregnant, which would make her expected delivery date from  September to  October.  While this was earlier than originally expected, the midwe did not recalculate this. Ms A was said to have engaged “minimally or not at all” with the midwe team and all antenatal care, including refusing to attend appointments for scans. In September, Ms A told a nurse that she would kill herself or someone her baby was taken away from her after birth a comment that prompted the nurse to discuss with an officer on duty whether it would be necessary to begin Prison Service suicide and self-harm monitoring. While they decided against this, Ms A was put on ‘extended observationsapos by the deputy head of healthcare on September . This meant she should have been checked by a nurse a minimum of twice during the day and twice at night. However, this did not happen. Ms A rang her cell bell shortly after pm that evening and asked for a nurse, though she did not say why. The officer who took the call handed over the information to a colleague, who spoke to Ms A on the phone but cannot remember the conversation.  “No nurse was called for Ms A. . Ms A pressed her cell bell again at .pm. The call was not answered on the house block and was erted to the permanently staffed communications room,” the report continued. “At .pm the call was connected and immediately disconnected. Ms A did not press her cell bell again.” Ms A’s cell was checked twice over the course of the night, but neither of the officers who carried out these checks noticed anything untoward, including blood, in her cell. It wasn’t until .am the next morning that an officer investigated and discovered Ms A had given birth during the night. Shortly after am paramedics confirmed her baby had died. Ms A was taken by ambulance to ASPH and ed to the prison that evening, where she was placed in the prison’s inpatient unit. The pathologist was unable to determine whether Baby A was born alive or was stillborn. The report outlined how the teenager “appeared to have been regarded as dficult and having a ‘bad attitude’ rather than as a vulnerable -year-old, frightened that her baby would be taken away”. Prisons and Probation ombudsman Sue McAllister told thethat Ms A should never have been left in a position where she was forced to give birth alone without medical assistance. The director of HMP Bronzefield called the incident “tragic and extremely sad”. “We are deeply sorry that this happened and our thoughts throughout have been with the family. In the two years which have passed, we have cooperated fully with the PPO investigation,” she said.Dr Kate Paradine, CEO of the charity Women in Prison,in  pleaded thatall mothers should have the right to give birth in dignity.She said: “But time and time again, we hear of situations where this isn’t happening, with mothers regularly being denied access to the vital health and maternity care necessary to give birth safely. This has devastating consequences not only for the baby and mother, but also for the rest of the family they are separated from. She added: Many mothers are imprisoned for being homeless, not having money to pay their bills and not having access to adequate mental health care and substance misuse support. Instead of sending these women to prison, the government needs to urgently prioritise investment in community support services like women’s centres, housing and health care.  Deputy prime minister and justice secretary, Dominic Raab also commented on the incident, which he said was “harrowing and unacceptable”. “We have already implemented the recommendation in the Prisons and Probation Ombudsman’s report. We have put in place important improvements to the care received by women in custody, and across government we must make sure that expectant mothers in prison get the same support as those in the community,” he said.Publication of the report has prompted the organisation of apetitionby organisations Level Up, Women In Prison and Birth Companions, calling for an end to the imprisonment of pregnant women. The groups’ calls have been echoed by the Royal College of Midwives and academics in the field. title: prince andrew finally accepts legal
story: :root Prince Andrew finally accepts legal papers have been served in sex assault caseThe Duke of York now officially has  days to respond to legal documents which accuse him of having sex with Virginia Giuffre against her willPrince Andrew has finally accepted legal papers Image: PAByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Sep Prince Andrew has finally accepted that he is in possession of legal papers relating to his sex assault case. The Duke of York now officially has  days to respond to legal documents which accuse him of having sex with Virginia Giuffre. The alleged sexual assaults took place at the behest of infamous billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein at properties in London, New York, and the US Virgin Islands. Ms Giuffreaposs lawyer, David Boies, says the prince - who is the Queenaposs second son - has accepted he is in possession of the papers.  The next legal step for the Duke is to ask for a reasonable extension of time to respond to Ms Giuffreaposs complaint. Mr Boies told the Daily Mail: Andrewaposs counsel have agreed that service has been made. Theoretically the clock is now ticking. However, it would be normal for them to ask for, and for us to agree to, a reasonable extension of time to respond to the complaint. A legal filing seen by the US publication also confirmed the documents had been served to the princeaposs lawyer, Andrew Brettler in Los Angeles.A source close to Andrew has claimed that despite his inner circle’s “deep reservations” that his “wall of silence” legal strategy was not working, he has decided to “keep faith and stay loyal” to his UK lawyer Gary Bloxsome of Blackfords.Royal insiders claimed that although the Duke has been stressed and worried over his predicament after Ms Giuffre accused him of sexually assaulting her three times in , the serving of legal papers effectively meant he had run out of time to change course. However, his newly appointed US attorney Andrew Brettler has now taken over the Duke’s case after being appointed just weeks ago. A source claimed the US team were “astonished” at the long held strategy of “no comment” employed by the Duke and his team as he became engulfed in sex abuse allegations by alleged former Jeffrey Epstein sex slave Virginia Giuffre. Another source close to Andrew said: “The Duke remains confident in his legal team and its strategy and is perfectly content to continue to follow their advice.”Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Prince Andrew, Duke of YorkRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: prince andrew should relinquish royal
story: :root Exclusive: Prince Andrew should relinquish royal title before Palace insists, says royal expertPrince Andrew should immediately give up his HRH title before the Palace insists on it, after he formally accepted Virginia Giuffres civil sex case papers, writes royal expert and author Nigel CawthorneIt could take five years for the civil case against Prince Andrew to rumble through the US courts Image: Getty ImagesopinionByNigel Cawthorne:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep Prince Andrew should give up his HRH title and any associated duties now that heaposs officially been served by his alleged sexual abuse victim.Following the initial serving of papers in August in the New York civil suit brought by Virginia Giuffre against Andrew, her lawyer David Boies again served papers in Los Angeles on Andrew Brettler as the princeaposs legal representative this Monday.As this is the route that Judge Kaplan suggested in the case, it is almost certain that Kaplan will imminently conclude Prince Andrew has been served.Finally, today, the news is that Andrew’s team has accepted the prince has been duly served. He now has  days to file a response, or risk a judgement by defaultJudge Kaplan considers the evidence brought by Giuffre compels him to do so in the absence of the princeaposs own evidence.As the case is now live, the massive immediate impact of the prince’s acceptance of the suit is not on the prince himself, however. If he contests the suit - which now seems very likely given his army of legal retainers - some experts have said the suit may take five years to reach a conclusion. That’s a long way off, and Andrew has already been living for almost two years behind palace gates with his spoiled dog.Its real weight now bears on the Palace, and particularly the long shadow of five years of legal skirmishes in the headlines. Is it proper for a member of the Royal Family to continue to retain their HRH title while a lawsuit proceeds against them  This is uncharted territory at best, as the prince is adamant that he has no case to answer and has consistently and strenuously denied Giuffreaposs accusations for as long as she has made them. Even so, appearing in court to contest an allegation is a grave matter in its own right. The Queen as head of state must surely rise above any reproach, and doubtless so should all HRHs in the Royal Family. Now that both sides in the suit agree papers have been served, it is dficult to see how the Palace can fail to insist that the prince relinquishes his HRH title to avoid any appearance of the monarchyaposs entanglement with a private matter that affects the prince only. In fact, Prince Andrew should probably offer to do so himself,he hasnapost already.*Nigel Cawthorne is the author of Prince Andrew: Epstein, Maxwell And The Palace Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON The QueenPrince Andrew, Duke of YorkRoyal Family" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
